description: Earth's origin, composition, structure, and natural resources. Plate tectonics as the driving force for volcanism, mountain building, and earthquakes.  Imaging Earth's interior. Environmental geoscience and sustainability. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list for the Faculty of Science section of  the Calendar.)
title: The Solid Earth: A Dynamic Planet

sections.comments: EOSC 111 is recommended.
EOSC 111 is recommended.
This section is reserved for UBC Vantage College students only.

preReqs: is full, please register on the waitlist.
description: An examination of the processes that shape and change the planet earth. This laboratory course is an appropriate complement to EOSC 110, EOSC 112, EOSC 114, EOSC 116 but can also be taken independently.
title: Laboratory Exploration of Planet Earth

description: Introduction to processes in ocean and atmosphere. Heat, current, winds, clouds, marine life, resources. Effects of coupling, climate change, pollution. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list, within the Faculty of Science section in the Calendar.)
title: The Fluid Earth: Atmosphere and Ocean

sections.comments: This course is part of the Climate Studies and Action Certificate: https://geog.ubc.ca/undergraduate/climate-certificate/
This course is part of the Climate Studies and Action Certificate: https://geog.ubc.ca/undergraduate/climate-certificate/

description: Introduction to causes and physical characteristics of disasters such as volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, tsunamis, hurricanes, storm surge, thunderstorms, tornadoes, landslides, wind waves, meteor impacts, mass extinctions.
title: The Catastrophic Earth: Natural Disasters

sections.comments: EOSC 114 99A is the distance education version of the course, covering the same materials, with the same homework and final exam. You will study at your own pace using online notes, with regular quizzes and discussions to focus and enhance your learning.If you are unable to join the in-person classes in sections 101/102 due to your schedule, please register for section 99A.

EOSC 114 99A is the distance education version of the course, covering the same materials, with the same homework and final exam. You will study at your own pace using online notes, with regular quizzes and discussions to focus and enhance your learning.If you are unable to join the in-person classes in sections 101/102 due to your schedule, please register for section 99A.

NOTE: All sections 99A are in Term 1 (Fall). All sections 99C are in Term 2 (Winter). EOSC 114 is a hybrid, asynchronous course for all students.  Course content is available directly on the course website or through links to outside resources. All Quizzes and Assignments are open over a set number of days for students to complete when it fits best within their own schedule. These are then submitted online, through the Course Website. There are no lectures to attend or video lectures to follow. The only time students need to attend a session in-person is for the written final exam. The final exam will be written during the UBC exam period, at a time and date arranged by UBC Exam Services. All students will attend the final exam in-person in a UBC classroom.

description: Earth's tectonics, climate, and oceans during the time of the dinosaurs.  Reading the fossil record of Earth from its earliest origins up to and including the Mesozoic, 250 - 65 million years ago.
title: Mesozoic Earth: Time of the Dinosaurs.

description: Origin, properties, valuation, prospecting and geology of gold, platinum, silver, diamonds, rubies, emeralds, and other precious metals and gems.
title: Earth's Treasures: Gold and Gems

preReqs: ble to register in the course, please register on the waitlist and you will be contacted if you are elligible to take the course.
description: Focus on the interaction between society and the geologic environment.  Locating, assessing and developing natural resources; understanding and preparing for natural hazards, design of structures and waste disposal sites.  For applied science and forestry students only.
title: Earth Science for Engineers

sections.comments: If you are unable to register in the course, please register on the waitlist and you will be contacted if you are elligible to take the course.

preReqs: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
description: Mathematical computer-based problem solving in the physical, chemical, and biological sciences. Problems drawn from studies of the earth, the oceans and the atmosphere. Credit will be granted for only one of APSC 160, CPSC 301, or EOSC 211.
title: Computer Methods in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences

sections.comments: If the course is full, please register on the waitlist.

description: Cutting edge problems in earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences.  Topics will be introduced through discussions of the current literature.
title: Topics in the Earth and Planetary Sciences.

preReqs: One of MATH 200, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of APSC 160, CPSC 103, CPSC 110, EOSC 211.
description: Combining basic physical principles with their mathematical description and generating computational models that describe them. Introduction to basic building blocks in modelling, simulation and parameter estimation.
title: Computational Methods in Geological Engineering

preReqs: One of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, SCIE 001.
description: Introduction to crystallography, physical and chemical properties of minerals. Recognition and identification of common minerals. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
title: Introductory Mineralogy

sections.comments: Restricted seats for MAJ EOSC students.

description: Optical mineralogy and the classification and genesis of igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks.
title: Introductory Petrology

preReqs: (Second-year standing in Science. One of EOSC 1**, EOSC 210, GEOB 103 is recommended.)
description: Measuring geological time and understanding Earth history using stratigraphic principles, paleontology and radioactive decay. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
title: Geological Time and Stratigraphy

sections.comments: Because of limited specimen availability, lab sizes are strictly limited. You are strongly encouraged to register in a lab section with smaller enrolment. If this is not possible, please register on the waitlist. Preference will be given to those registered in EOAS programs.

Because of limited specimen availability, lab sizes are strictly limited. You are strongly encouraged to register in a lab section with smaller enrolment. If this is not possible, please register on the waitlist. Preference will be given to those registered in EOAS programs.

description: Introduction to the techniques of geological mapping and the interpretation of field data. Includes three one-day field trips on weekends plus a seven-day field school after Spring examinations. A fee is to be paid by January 31.
title: Field Techniques

sections.comments: Seven day field school held after final exams. An additional fee will be charged for this course.Two required field trips on weekends during T2.If this section is BLOCKED/FULL, please register on the waitlist (EOSC 223.WL2).

Seven day Field School held after final exams. Additional fee charged for this course.EOSC 223.201: Two required field trips on weekends during the term.If this section is BLOCKED/FULL, please register on the waitlist (EOSC 223.W2L).

description: Theory and practice of site investigation for geological engineers, including background studies, field work, remote sensing, development of ground models, importance of geological variability and uncertainty. Impacts on design, project risk and decision making.
title: Site Investigation

preReqs: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157.
description: Application of classical theory of scalar and vector fields to geophysical sciences. Conductive, convective and radiative energy flux, gravitation, electrostatics, and magnetostatics. Gauss' and Stokes' theorems.
title: Fields and Fluxes

preReqs: One of SCIE 001, CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 154.
description: Introduction to diversity of marine habitats and ecosystems; hydrothermal vent, intertidal, coral reef, estuarine, deep sea, and polar ecosystems; impacts of ecosystem change; evolution of ocean plankton; invasive species; climate change; pollution.
title: Marine Ecosystems

description: The Earth as a planet: its composition, internal dynamics, and surface evolution. Rotation, magnetic field, plate tectonics, earthquakes, volcanoes. The ocean, atmosphere, and biosphere as components of a varying geo-environment. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science and Applied Science. No background in science or mathematics is required. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
title: The Earth and the Solar System

sections.comments: NOTE: All sections 99A are in Term 1 (Fall). All sections 99C are in Term 2 (Winter). EOSC 310 is a hybrid, asynchronous course for all students.  There is a textbook for this course. All Quizzes and Assignments are open over a set number of days for students to complete when it fits best within their own schedule. These are then submitted online, through the Course Website. There are no lectures to attend or video lectures to follow. The only time students need to attend a session in-person is for the written final exam. The final exam will be written during the UBC exam period, at a time and date arranged by UBC Exam Services. All students will attend the final exam in-person in a UBC classroom.

description: An introduction to the oceans and the processes that have shaped them, their composition and movement, waves, tides, beaches, interactions with the atmosphere and human exploitation of the non-living resources. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science. No background in Science or Mathematics is required.
title: The Ocean Environment

sections.comments: NOTE: All sections 99A are in Term 1 (Fall). All sections 99C are in Term 2 (Winter). EOSC 314 is a hybrid, asynchronous course for all students.  Course content is available directly on the course website or through links to outside resources. All Quizzes and Assignments are open over a set number of days for students to complete when it fits best within their own schedule. These are then submitted online, through the Course Website. There are no lectures to attend or video lectures to follow. The only time students need to attend a session in-person is for the written final exam. The final exam will be written during the UBC exam period, at a time and date arranged by UBC Exam Services. All students will attend the final exam in-person in a UBC classroom.

description: An introduction to life in the oceans, its variety and evolution; primary producers and their links to the environment, zooplankton, marine communities, living marine resources and their role in today's world. Not for credit in the Faculties of Science or Applied Science.
title: The Ocean Ecosystem

sections.comments: NOTE: All sections 99A are in Term 1 (Fall). All sections 99C are in Term 2 (Winter). EOSC 315 is a hybrid, asynchronous course for all students.  Course content is available directly on the course website or through links to outside resources. All Quizzes and Assignments are open over a set number of days for students to complete when it fits best within their own schedule. These are then submitted online, through the Course Website. There are no lectures to attend or video lectures to follow. The only time students need to attend a session in-person is for the written final exam. The final exam will be written during the UBC exam period, at a time and date arranged by UBC Exam Services. All students will attend the final exam in-person in a UBC classroom.

preReqs: EOSC 221 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.
description: Origin, diagenesis and geochemistry of sediments and sedimentary rocks.
title: Sedimentology

description: The origin and formation of igneous rocks.
title: Igneous Petrology

sections.comments: Pre-requisite: EOSC 221.

description: Deciphering lithospheric processes as recorded by the mineralogy, chemistry and textures of metamorphosed rocks.
title: Metamorphic Petrology

preReqs: All of EOSC 221, EOSC 223 and one of EOSC 210, EOSC 222.
description: Analysis and interpretation of natural deformation.
title: Structural Geology I

sections.comments: In order to register for this course, students must have completed all of EOSC 221, EOSC 222, EOSC 223.For Fall 2020, EOSC 323 will involve regular online synchronous lectures (2 per week), which will be recorded, providing opportunities to participate in class activities and discussions with your instructors and your peers. Labs will run synchronously, to provide full support from your TAs. Please select a lab section that you are able to attend on a regular basis. Instructor office hours / tutorial times will be determined based on a student survey at the start of the semester.

preReqs: (3rd year standing in Science, Land and Food Systems or Forestry; and)
description: Theories of storage and movement of water within groundwater systems; Groundwater-surface water interaction; Role of groundwater systems in watershed management and regulating the environmental impacts of global change; Groundwater sustainability; Impacts of climate and land use changes on groundwater resources
title: Principles of Physical Hydrogeology

sections.comments: If pre-requisites are not met and unable to register, please contact instructor directly for permission.

description: The fossil record of adaptation and extinction emphasizing the interaction of biological and geological processes. Not for credit in Geological Sciences and Geophysics specializations. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: http://www.calendar.ubc.ca/vancouver/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
title: Earth and Life Through Time

sections.comments: Please register on the wait list when the course is full. In order to register for this course, students must have completed at least 3 credits of 100 level Biology. Two weeks (usually but not always in October) are used for fossil activities during scheduled lesson times. More information will be provided by the instructor.

NOTE: All sections 99A are in Term 1 (Fall). All sections 99C are in Term 2 (Winter). EOSC 326 is a hybrid, asynchronous course for all students.  All course content is available directly on the course website or through links to outside resources. There is no textbook for this course. All Quizzes and Assignments are open over a set number of days for students to complete when it fits best within their own schedule. These are then submitted online, through the Course Website. There are no lectures to attend or video lectures to follow. The only time students need to attend a session in-person is for the written final exam. The final exam will be written during the UBC exam period, at a time and date arranged by UBC Exam Services. All students will attend the final exam in-person in a UBC and ~ classroom.

preReqs: All of EOSC 323, EOSC 330 and one of EOSC 321, EOSC 322.
description: Recording and processing geological data in the field. Held within the three weeks following April examinations after third year. A special fee is to be paid by January 31.
title: Field Geology

sections.comments: A 3-week field school which begins after April exams. Substantial additional fees required. Several informational meetings will be held before the end of term. Email instructor regarding registration if the course is full. The purchase of some geological mapping equipment will be required for this course, see website for details.Field School runs in May 2017.

preReqs: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121, SCIE 001.
description: Introduction to theory of groundwater flow; flow nets; regional groundwater resource evaluation; well hydraulics; role of groundwater in geologic processes, case studies.
title: Quantitative Groundwater Hydrology

description: Landform development; morphological and historical analysis of landforms; applications in engineering and resource development. Please consult the Faculty of Science Credit Exclusion List: www.students.ubc.ca/calendar/index.cfm?tree=12,215,410,414.
title: Principles of Geomorphology

sections.comments: GEOG 206 and GEOG 306 is equivalent for P.Geo. The lab sections of EOSC 330 will not be finalized until early September.

description: Introduction to economic geology and models related to mineral exploration. Study includes typical deposit types and their plate tectonic setting.
title: Introduction to Mineral Deposits

description: An overview of the geology and tectonic evolution of North America; comparisons and contrasts between Precambrian rocks of the North American craton and Phanerozoic belts of the Cordilleran, Appalachian, Ouachita and Innuitian orogens;  interrelations between sedimentation, deformation, metamorphism and magmatism in a plate tectonic context.
title: Tectonic Evolution of North America

description: Analytical methods in geochemistry, major and trace element geochemistry, radiogenic isotopes, geochemistry of seawater, the mantle, basalts, subduction zones, sedimentary rocks, continental crust.
title: Elemental and Isotopic Geochemistry

sections.comments: Students must have pre-requisite: EOSC 221.Book Summary:Geochemistry, W.M. White, Wiley-Blackwell, April 2013.Geochemistry: An Introduction, F. Albarede, Cambridge University Press, 2009.

preReqs: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.
description: Mechanisms and processes of past and future global environmental and climate change.
title: Global Climate Change

sections.comments: This course is part of the Climate Studies and Action Certificate: https://geog.ubc.ca/undergraduate/climate-certificate/
This course is part of the Climate Studies and Action Certificate: https://geog.ubc.ca/undergraduate/climate-certificate/

preReqs: One of MATH 200, MATH 253. (and third-year standing or higher in Science or Applied Science.)
description: Principles of geophysical survey design, data acquisition, processing and interpretation with emphasis on near-surface problems. Magnetic, seismic reflection/refraction, electromagnetic and ground penetrating radar surveys. Case history analysis of environmental and geotechnical problems.
title: Environmental, Geotechnical, and Exploration Geophysics I

description: Introduction to tensor calculus and continuum mechanics. Stress, strain and strain-rate tensors. Mass, momentum and energy balance. Applications to problems of geophysical heat transport, elasticity and fluid dynamics.
title: Geophysical Continuum Dynamics

description: Hooke's law for isotropic continua, elastic wave equation, reflection and refraction methods for imaging the Earth's internal structure, plane waves in an infinite medium and interaction with boundaries, body wave seismology, inversion of travel-time curves, generalized ray theory, crustal seismology, surface waves and earthquake source studies.
title: Seismology

sections.comments: Course not offered in 2020W

preReqs: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157.
description: Continuous and discrete Fourier transforms, correlation and convolution, spectral estimates, optimum least-squares filters, deconvolution and prediction, frequency-wave number filtering. A practical course on computer techniques applied to the analysis of a wide range of geophysical phenomena.
title: Analysis of Time Series and Inverse Theory for Earth Scientists

preReqs: Either (a) SCIE 001 or (b) one of CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, CHEM 154 and one of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.
description: Physical and chemical processes and their controls on the distribution of plankton in the ocean.
title: Introductory Oceanography: Circulation and Plankton

sections.comments: - EOSC 372 can not be taken by students who have credit for MRNE 435.- Students in the Environmental Engineering program should register on the waitlist and contact the EOAS Undergraduate Program Coordinator at ugradsec@eoas.ubc.ca; to be transfered into the course.

description: Physical, chemical, and biological processes in the ocean and their interaction with climate and marine food-webs.
title: Introductory Oceanography: Climate and Ecosystems

sections.comments: EOSC 373 can not be taken by students who have credit for MRNE 435.

description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following second year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.
title: Co-operative Work Placement I

sections.comments: Discuss options with your supervisor.
Discuss options with your supervisor.

description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university or government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in Winter Session (Term 1) in third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.
title: Co-operative Work Placement II

sections.comments: Discuss options with your supervisor.
Discuss options with your supervisor.
Discuss options with your supervisor.

preReqs: One of STAT 200, BIOL 300 and one of MATH 200, EOSC 250 and EOSC 211 and one of EOSC 212, ENVR 300 and one of CPSC 203, CPSC 210. (And third-year standing in Geophysics, Environmental Science, Earth and Ocean Science, Atmospheric Science, Geology, Oceanography or Geological Engineering;)
description: Application of data analysis and empirical modelling strategies for conducting a data-oriented research in geosciences; from setting research questions and hypothesis to delivering and interpreting results. Examples are drawn from across the Earth, ocean, atmospheric and planetary sciences.
title: Geoscientific Data Analysis and Empirical Modelling

description: Field and lab-based studies in volcanology concentrating on physical and chemical aspects of volcanic processes.
title: Volcanology

sections.comments: Course not offered in 2020WThis is a 4th year capstone course. The lectures, labs, research projects, and field projects are mandatory. This course is restricted to students with equal or above 3rd year standing in Science, in the following specializations: MAJ GEOL, HON GEOL, MAJ EOSC, and equal or above 3rd year standing in Applied Science in GEO/ENG.EOSC 321 is strongly recommended.

description: Studies of natural deformation using advanced techniques.
title: Structural Geology II

description: Paleobiogeography in the context of plate tectonics. Mass extinction events. Fossilization and biases in the fossil record. Species concepts in paleontology. Biostratigraphy. Paleontological evidence for early life; the colonization of oceanic and terrestrial environments and; the evolution of the primates.
title: Paleontology

preReqs: One of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 121, CHEM 110, CHEM 111, CHEM 120, CHEM 121, EOSC 110, EOSC 112. (Third year standing in Science.)
description: Foundational knowledge of the interactions between microorganisms and Earth's surface chemistry.
title: Fundamentals of Geomicrobiology

description: Hydraulic head measurements, water-quality sampling, pump and slug testing, infiltration measurements, profiling techniques. Held over five days after spring term at the Richmond groundwater hydrology field-school site. Enrolment limitations.
title: Field Techniques in Groundwater Hydrology

description: Contaminant transport processes in groundwater flow systems; aqueous and multiphase transport; mathematical models describing migration and chemical evolution of contaminant plumes; case studies.
title: Groundwater Contamination

description: Origin, geochemistry and distribution of petroleum and coal in the stratigraphic record. Sedimentation of organic matter, organic diagenesis, migration and accumulation of hydrocarbons. Principles of exploration and development. Techniques for measurement of organic maturation and source rock analyses.
title: Fossil Fuels

description: Application of rock mechanics, hydrogeology, and engineering design tools in realistically complex geological environments. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty, and use of field data, geotechnical monitoring, and numerical analyses for tunnelling, mining and rock slope engineering projects. Case histories.
title: Geological Engineering Practice I - Rock Engineering

description: Application of geomorphology, hydrogeology, and soil mechanics to geotechnical design. Influence and treatment of geological uncertainty in geotechnical hazard and risk assessments; multi-disciplinary approaches to geotechnical engineering problems in realistically complex geological environments. Case histories.
title: Geological Engineering Practice II - Soil Engineering

preReqs: EOSC 340 and one of CPSC 103, CPSC 110, CPSC 301, EOSC 211, MATH 210, PHYS 210 and one of STAT 200, STAT 201, STAT 251, BIOL 300.
description: Local climate time series collection and analysis. Retrieval and analysis of online climate data and model output.
title: Climate Measurement and Analysis

description: Geological engineering design project from scope definition to final design.  Based on a problem from industry.
title: Engineering Design Project

description: For B.A.Sc. Topic to be approved by the Department.
title: Thesis

description: Original research work under the direction of a faculty member. Required of all honours students. Open to major students with a satisfactory standing, appropriate background courses and permission of the course instructor and the directing faculty member.
title: Thesis

description: Identification and quantitative analysis of diverse physical problems in the earth, ocean, atmospheric, and planetary sciences.
title: Physics of the Earth and Other Planets

sections.comments: MATH 316 or PHYS 312 to be taken concurrently with EOSC 453.

description: A quantitative examination of processes regulating the abundance, distribution and production of phytoplankton, zooplankton, microbes and fish. Controls of primary and secondary production, ecosystem dynamics and foodwebs.
title: Biological Oceanography

sections.comments: Pre-requisites: One of EOSC 372, EOSC 373, BIOL305.

preReqs: EOSC 211 and one of ATSC 201, EOSC 372, GEOB 200 and one of SCIE 001, PHYS 101, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 153, PHYS 157.
description: Use of observations, theory and model results to solve physical oceanographic problems including applications to transport and mixing of pollutants or nutrients.
title: Waves, Currents and Ocean Mixing

description: Controls on chemical composition and elemental distributions in seawater and marine sediments (including nutrient elements, dissolved gases, the carbonate system, marine organic matter, and trace metals); solution chemistry of seawater; isotopic tracers of rates and dates in marine systems; geochemical balance in the oceans.
title: Chemical Oceanography and Marine Geochemistry

description: Methods of data acquisition, study and analysis required in solving oceanographic problems. Includes a field school held during the mid-term break. A fee is to be paid by January 31. Open to third- and fourth-year students in Oceanography, or with permission of the Department Head.
title: Methods in Oceanography

sections.comments: Please contact Maite Maldonado at mmaldonado@eos.ubc.ca to inquire about registration. Includes a field component, during Reading Week.

description: An interdisciplinary study of pollution, with examples drawn from coastal and oceanic environments, including areas of local interest. Intended for third and fourth year students with a background in the sciences.
title: Marine Pollution

preReqs: (A minimum of 6 credits of third-year level life science courses.)
description: Advanced biology, ecology and diversity of marine microbes. Emphasis on the roles of bacteria and viruses in marine foodwebs and geochemical cycles.
title: Marine Microbiology

description: An introduction to the ecology and management of freshwater and marine fisheries. Topics include: population dynamics, species interactions, communities, environmental influences, stock assessment, economics and sociology of fisheries. Laboratories will consist of numerical analyses and simulations.
title: Introduction to Fisheries Science

description: Approved and supervised technical work experience in an industrial, university of government setting for a minimum of 14 weeks. Normally taken in the Summer Session (Terms 1 and 2) following third year. Technical report required. Restricted to students admitted to the Co-operative Education Option in Earth, Ocean and Atmospheric Sciences.
title: Co-operative Work Placement III

sections.comments: Restricted to co-op placement.

description: Crystal structure, chemistry, origin and paragenesis of major rock-forming and ore minerals.
title: Advanced Mineralogy

title: Methods and Modelling in Petrology and Geochemistry

description: Lectures and laboratory problems.
title: Mechanics of Natural Deformation

description: The origin and character of coal and associated strata. Petrology, chemistry and physical properties of coal. Sedimentology of peat, biochemical and geochemical stages of coalification and oxidation of coal. Use of organic matter as a geothermometer and inbasinal analysis. Structural analysis and character of coal deposits. Analytical methods applied to coal.
title: Advanced Coal Geology

sections.comments: Scheduled for Wed 14:00 - 16:00. Room TBA

description: Hydraulic head measurements, water-quality sampling, pump and slug testing, infiltration measurements, profiling techniques. Computer analysis of field data. Held after spring term at the Richmond groundwater hydrology field site. Enrolment limitations.
title: Field Laboratory in Groundwater Hydrology

preReqs: l be offered in a hybrid format with both in class and online meetings
description: Finite-difference models of steady-state and transient groundwater flow in the saturated and unsaturated zones; applications to regional groundwater flow, groundwater recharge, subsurface contributions to streamflow, and aquifer evaluation.
title: Advanced Groundwater Hydrology

sections.comments: The course will be offered in a hybrid format with both in class and online meetings
